title: One-Step Inequalities

concept.what_is_it: A one-step inequality is like a one-step equation — except instead of showing equality, it shows how one side is greater or less than the other.
concept.kid_friendly_explanation: An inequality is a math sentence that says one side is bigger or smaller. Solving it means finding all the numbers that make that sentence true — not just one answer! The trick is: treat it like an equation, but if you multiply or divide by a negative number, FLIP the inequality sign.

key_points: Isolate the variable using the inverse operation.
Use the opposite operation to undo what's happening to the variable.
If you multiply or divide both sides by a negative, flip the inequality sign.
Graph your answer on a number line:
kid_friendly_explainer: One-step inequalities work just like one-step equations! The difference? Instead of finding ONE answer, you're finding a whole bunch of numbers that work. For example, if $x > 5$, that means $x$ could be 6, 7, 100, or even 5.1 — anything greater than 5!
To solve a one-step inequality, you do exactly what you'd do for an equation: use inverse operations to get $x$ alone. Add to undo subtraction, multiply to undo division, and so on.

But here's the ONE SUPER IMPORTANT RULE: When you multiply or divide BOTH sides by a negative number, you must FLIP the inequality sign! $>$ becomes $<$, and $\ge$ becomes $\le$. This is because the relationship changes when you go into negative territory.

Once you solve it, you can show your answer on a number line. Use an open circle (○) for $<$ or $>$ (the number isn't included), and a filled circle (●) for $\le$ or $\ge$ (the number IS included). Then draw an arrow in the direction where all the solutions are!
step_by_step: Look at what operation is being done to the variable (add, subtract, multiply, or divide).
Do the opposite (inverse) operation to both sides to isolate the variable.
If you multiply or divide by a negative, flip the inequality.
Graph the final answer on a number line.

walkthrough: Graph: Open circle at 3, arrow to the right
Graph: Filled circle at 3, arrow to the right
Graph: Open circle at -2, arrow to the left
Graph: Open circle at 10, arrow to the left

mini_examples.graph_explanation: Draw a filled circle at 1 and shade to the right for greater than or equal to.
Draw a filled circle at 3 and shade to the left for less than or equal to.
Draw an open circle at -3 and shade to the left.

tips: Always keep your variable on the left for clarity.
If the inequality looks confusing, test a number to check your direction.
Remember: flipping only happens with multiplication or division by a negative!
teacher_notes: Always keep your variable on the left for clarity.
If the inequality looks confusing, test a number to check your direction.
Remember: flipping only happens with multiplication or division by a negative!
On a number line: open circle for $<$ or $>$; filled circle for $\le$ or $\ge$.
Arrow points right for 'greater than', left for 'less than'.
Interval notation: use parentheses $()$ for open circles, brackets $[]$ for filled circles.
The flipping rule is critical — reinforce this with examples showing why it makes sense mathematically.
common_mistakes: Forgetting to flip the inequality sign after dividing or multiplying by a negative.
Using a filled circle for < or > (should be open).
Shading in the wrong direction on the number line.

easy.directions: Solve each inequality and describe how to graph it.

items.solution: $x>3$ → Open circle at 3, shade right. Interval: $(3,\infty)$
$x\le10$ → Filled circle at 10, shade left. Interval: $(-\infty,10]$
$x\ge3$ → Filled circle at 3, shade right. Interval: $[3,\infty)$
$x<10$ → Open circle at 10, shade left. Interval: $(-\infty,10)$

medium.directions: Watch for negative coefficients! Remember to flip the sign.

items.solution: $x\le4$ → Filled circle at 4, shade left. Interval: $(-\infty,4]$
$x<-2$ → Open circle at -2, shade left (flipped!). Interval: $(-\infty,-2)$
$x\ge2$ → Filled circle at 2, shade right. Interval: $[2,\infty)$
$x\ge-6$ → Filled circle at -6, shade right (flipped!). Interval: $[-6,\infty)$

challenge.directions: Advanced problems with fractions and negative coefficients.

items.solution: $x<12$ → Open circle at 12, shade left (flipped!). Interval: $(-\infty,12)$
$x\ge-2$ → Filled circle at -2, shade right (flipped!). Interval: $[-2,\infty)$
$x<\dfrac{5}{4}$ → Open circle at 1.25, shade left. Interval: $(-\infty,\frac{5}{4})$
$x<-6$ → Open circle at -6, shade left (flipped!). Interval: $(-\infty,-6)$

extreme.directions: Expert-level problems with decimals and complex fractions.

items.solution: $x\ge-20$ → Filled circle at -20, shade right (flipped!). Interval: $[-20,\infty)$
$x\ge10$ → Filled circle at 10, shade right. Interval: $[10,\infty)$
$x>4$ → Open circle at 4, shade right (flipped!). Interval: $(4,\infty)$

self_check.question: When solving inequalities, when should you flip the sign?
choices: When you multiply or divide by a negative number
self_check.answer: When you multiply or divide by a negative number.
